abstract: A behavior that applies a continuous or instantaneous force to one or more dynamic items, causing those items to change position accordingly.
overview:
## Overview

A *dynamic item* is any iOS or custom object that conforms to the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicItem] protocol. The [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIView] and [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UICollectionViewLayoutAttributes] classes implement this protocol starting in iOS 7.0. You can use a custom object as a dynamic item for such purposes as reacting to rotation or position changes computed by a dynamic animator—an instance of the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicAnimator] class.

The default magnitude of a push behavior’s force vector is `nil`, equivalent to no force. A continuous force vector with a magnitude of `1.0`, applied to a 100 point x 100 point view whose density value is `1.0`, results in view acceleration of 100 points / second² in the direction of the vector; this value is also known as the UIKit Newton.

You express a push behavior’s force vector in terms of magnitude ([doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/magnitude]) and radian angle ([doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/angle]). Instead of using radian angle, you can equivalently express direction using *x* and *y* components by using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/pushDirection] property. Whichever approach you use, the alternate, equivalent values update automatically.

For each dynamic item that you associate with a push, the force is applied at the item center or at a specified offset from the center in item-relative coordinates.

To use a push behavior with a dynamic item, perform these two steps:

After enabling a push behavior, you can activate it and deactivate it using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/active] property.

The coordinate system that pertains to a push behavior, and the types of dynamic items you can use with the behavior, depend on how you initialized the associated animator. For details, read the Overview of [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicAnimator].

You can include a push behavior in a custom, composite behavior by starting with a [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicBehavior] object and adding a push behavior with the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicBehavior/addChildBehavior(_:)] method.  If you want to influence a push behavior at each step of a dynamic animation, implement the inherited [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicBehavior/action] method.
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior
crawled: 2025-12-02T15:26:59Z
---

# UIPushBehavior

**Class**

A behavior that applies a continuous or instantaneous force to one or more dynamic items, causing those items to change position accordingly.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor class UIPushBehavior
```

## Overview

A *dynamic item* is any iOS or custom object that conforms to the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicItem] protocol. The [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIView] and [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UICollectionViewLayoutAttributes] classes implement this protocol starting in iOS 7.0. You can use a custom object as a dynamic item for such purposes as reacting to rotation or position changes computed by a dynamic animator—an instance of the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicAnimator] class.

The default magnitude of a push behavior’s force vector is `nil`, equivalent to no force. A continuous force vector with a magnitude of `1.0`, applied to a 100 point x 100 point view whose density value is `1.0`, results in view acceleration of 100 points / second² in the direction of the vector; this value is also known as the UIKit Newton.

You express a push behavior’s force vector in terms of magnitude ([doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/magnitude]) and radian angle ([doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/angle]). Instead of using radian angle, you can equivalently express direction using *x* and *y* components by using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/pushDirection] property. Whichever approach you use, the alternate, equivalent values update automatically.

For each dynamic item that you associate with a push, the force is applied at the item center or at a specified offset from the center in item-relative coordinates.

To use a push behavior with a dynamic item, perform these two steps:

1. Associate the item with the behavior using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/addItem(_:)] method, or initialize a new push behavior with an array of items using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/init(items:mode:)] method
2. Enable the behavior by adding it to an animator using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicAnimator/addBehavior(_:)] method

After enabling a push behavior, you can activate it and deactivate it using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIPushBehavior/active] property.

The coordinate system that pertains to a push behavior, and the types of dynamic items you can use with the behavior, depend on how you initialized the associated animator. For details, read the Overview of [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicAnimator].

You can include a push behavior in a custom, composite behavior by starting with a [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicBehavior] object and adding a push behavior with the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicBehavior/addChildBehavior(_:)] method.  If you want to influence a push behavior at each step of a dynamic animation, implement the inherited [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIDynamicBehavior/action] method.

## Initializing and managing a push behavior

- **active**: The state of the push behavior’s force: either active or inactive.
- **addItem(_:)**: Adds a dynamic item to the behavior’s dynamic item array.
- **init(items:mode:)**: Initializes a push behavior with an array of dynamic items.
- **removeItem(_:)**: Removes a specific dynamic item from the behavior.
- **items**: Returns the set of dynamic items you’ve added to the push behavior.

## Configuring a push behavior

- **setAngle(_:magnitude:)**: Sets the angle and magnitude of the force vector for the behavior.
- **angle**: The angle, in radians, of the force vector for the behavior.
- **magnitude**: The magnitude of the force vector for the push behavior.
- **mode**: Returns the force mode for the push behavior.
- **setTargetOffsetFromCenter(_:for:)**: Sets the offset, from the center of a dynamic item, at which to apply the push behavior’s force vector.
- **targetOffsetFromCenter(for:)**: Returns the offset, from the center of a dynamic item, at which the push behavior’s force vector is applied.
- **pushDirection**: The direction of the force vector for the behavior, expressed as *x* and *y* components and using standard UIKit geometry.

## Constants

- **UIPushBehavior.Mode**: The type of force for the push behavior.

## Behaviors

- **UIDynamicBehavior**: An object that confers a behavioral configuration on one or more dynamic items, for their participation in 2D animation.
- **UIAttachmentBehavior**: A relationship between two dynamic items, or between a dynamic item and an anchor point.
- **UICollisionBehavior**: An object that confers to a specified array of dynamic items the ability to engage in collisions with each other and with the behavior’s specified boundaries.
- **UIFieldBehavior**: An object that applies field-based physics to dynamic items.
- **UIGravityBehavior**: An object that applies a gravity-like force to all of its associated dynamic items.
- **UISnapBehavior**: A spring-like behavior whose initial motion is damped over time so that the object settles at a specific point.

## Inherits From

- UIDynamicBehavior

## Conforms To

- CVarArg
- CustomDebugStringConvertible
- CustomStringConvertible
- Equatable
- Hashable
- NSObjectProtocol
- Sendable
- SendableMetatype
